[/quote]
It’s what you’re using to style your website.

Don’t use tables for styling, use CSS.
http://www.w3schools.com/[/quote]isn’t CSS = Cascading Style Sheet?

item.title: Need some HTML help
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“Natey, post:22, topic:341689”]I think mine looks good atm o.o

I want like the silab client for a webclient but that’s impossible.[/quote]Just an idea for your website, you have your list like

  • Item 1

    *Item 2 etc, but you can do it with an ordered or unordered list.
    For example, try this:

[code=html4strict]

Updates as of 5/26/2010

  • Deleted blood runes, so no duping!
  • Added godsword stances (not real RS's)
[/code]

Read full topic

item.title: Need some HTML help
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“Natey, post:20, topic:341689”][quote author=justinxg27 link=topic=438087.msg3220164#msg3220164 date=1275104408]
Chuck some tables in dude
[/quote]what are tables?[/quote]Tables are an old way to lay out a webpage, or to display information.

It’s basically an excel spreadsheet, separated by rows and columns.
To start a table:

[code=html4strict]

[/code] The first line starts the table. The border is the line around each cell of the table (indicated by # of pixels wide), and the others indicate how many rows/columns the table will have.

The

tag starts a new row of the table.
The tag starts a new cell of the row. You put any information inside the cell.

[code=html4strict]

1,1 1,2
2,1 2,2
[/code]

Read full topic

item.title: Need some HTML help
item.dc:creator: @Natey Natey
item.description:
@Natey wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:16, topic:341689”][quote author=Natey link=topic=438087.msg3219909#msg3219909 date=1275087163]
Yeah, I found that out.

I added the page in my sig, check it out
[/quote]Not bad, but not the best. Here are some ideas:

  1. In the head, (in between the tags) add some CSS to change the link colors. The default blue is hard to read on black. Here is the code:

<style type="text/css"> a:link { color:white; text-decoration:none; } a:hover { color:white; text-decoration:underline; } a:visited { color:white; } </style>This also adds a hover effect.[/quote]Thanks, will do.
You think you can add me on my msn?
Just PM me for my email

Read full topic

item.title: Need some HTML help
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“Natey, post:15, topic:341689”]Yeah, I found that out.

I added the page in my sig, check it out :D[/quote]Not bad, but not the best. Here are some ideas:

  1. In the head, (in between the tags) add some CSS to change the link colors. The default blue is hard to read on black. Here is the code:

<style type="text/css"> a:link { color:white; text-decoration:none; } a:hover { color:white; text-decoration:underline; } a:visited { color:white; } </style>This also adds a hover effect.

Read full topic

item.title: Need some HTML help
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“Natey, post:7, topic:341689”]Davidi, do you know how to display another webpage within another?

Like if I were to click the “Forums” link on my home page “example.host.com/forumz/test.htm”
it would redirect to “example.host.com/forumz/newpage.htm” and then display another weblike like moparscape, or my forums, etc.[/quote]Like x said, IFrame works. When I was developing for my school website, we had a newsletter page. We then used an anchor onClick event to change the source of the iframe to the newsletter you clicked on. It’s a simple concept.

Read full topic

it would redirect to “example.host.com/forumz/newpage.htm” and then display another weblike like moparscape, or my forums, etc.[/quote][code]

it would redirect to “example.host.com/forumz/newpage.htm” and then display another weblike like moparscape, or my forums, etc.[/quote] you could use an iframe if i understand thats what you want. the way for xhtml i hear is through the object tag. i like www.w3schools.com i find it useful. it actual helped me a couple years ago understand programming a lil better.
